\title[A normal generating set for ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)$]
{A normal generating set for the Torelli group of a compact non-orientable surface}

\maketitle















\begin{abstract}
For a compact surface $S$, let ${\mathcal{I}}(S)$ denote the \textit{Torelli group} of $S$.
For a compact orientable surface $\Sigma$, ${\mathcal{I}}(\Sigma)$ is generated by \textit{BSCC maps} and \textit{BP maps} (see \cite{Po} and \cite{Pu}).
For a non-orientable closed surface $N$, ${\mathcal{I}}(N)$ is generated by BSCC maps and BP maps (see \cite{HK}).
In this paper, we give an explicit normal generating set for ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)$, where $N_g^b$ is a genus-$g$ compact non-orientable surface with $b$ boundary components for $g\geq4$ and $b\geq1$.
\end{abstract}




















\section{Introduction}

For $g\geq1$ and $b\geq0$, let $N_g^b$ denote a genus-$g$ compact connected non-orientable surface with $b$ boundary components, and let $N_g=N_g^0$.
In this paper, we regard $N_g^b$ as a surface obtained by attaching $g$ M\"obius bands to a sphere with $g+b$ boundary components, as shown in Figure~\ref{non-ori}.
We say each of these M\"obius bands attached to this sphere a \textit{cross cap}.
The \textit{mapping class group} ${\mathcal{M}}(N_g^b)$ of $N_g^b$ is the group consisting of isotopy classes of all diffeomorphisms over $N_g^b$ which fix each point of the boundary.
The \textit{Torelli group} ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)$ of $N_g^b$ is the subgroup of ${\mathcal{M}}(N_g^b)$ consisting of elements acting trivially on the integral first homology group $H_1(N_g^b;{\mathbb{Z}})$ of $N_g^b$.
The Torelli group of a compact orientable surface is generated by \textit{BSCC maps} and \textit{BP maps} (see \cite{Po} and \cite{Pu}).
In particular, Johnson \cite{J} showed that the Torelli group of an orientable closed surface is finitely generated by BP maps.
Hirose and the author \cite{HK} showed that ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g)$ is generated by BSCC maps and BP maps for $g\geq4$.
In this paper, we give an explicit normal generating set for ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)$ consisting of BSCC maps and BP maps, for $g\geq4$ and $b\geq1$.


\begin{figure}[htbp]
\includegraphics[scale=0.5]{non-ori.eps}
\caption{A genus-$g$ compact connected non-orientable surface with $b$ boundary components.}\label{non-ori}
\end{figure}


Let $N$ be a compact connected non-orientable surface.
For a simple closed curve $c$ on $N$, we call $c$ an \textit{$A$-circle} (resp. an \textit{$M$-circle}) if its regular neighborhood is an annulus (resp. a M\"obius band), as shown in Figure~\ref{a-m}.
For an $A$-circle $c$, we can define the mapping class $t_c$, called the \textit{Dehn twist} about $c$, and the direction of the twist is indicated by a small arrow written beside $c$ as shown in Figure~\ref{dehn}.
We can notice that an $A$-circle (resp. an $M$-circle) passes through cross caps even times (resp. odd times).

Let $\alpha$, $\beta$, $\beta^\prime$, $\gamma$, $\delta_i$, $\rho_i$ and $\sigma_{ij}$ be simple closed curves on $N_g^b$ as shown in Figure~\ref{loops}.
The main result of this paper is as follows.



\begin{thm}\label{main-thm}
Let $g\geq5$ and $b\geq0$.
In ${\mathcal{M}}(N_g^b)$, ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)$ is normally generated by $t_\alpha$, $t_\beta{}t_{\beta^\prime}^{-1}$, $t_{\delta_i}$, $t_{\rho_i}$ and $t_{\sigma_{ij}}$ for $1\leq{i,j}\leq{b-1}$ with $i<j$.
In ${\mathcal{M}}(N_4^b)$, ${\mathcal{I}}(N_4^b)$ is normally generated by $t_\alpha$, $t_\beta{}t_{\beta^\prime}^{-1}$, $t_{\delta_i}$, $t_{\rho_i}$, $t_{\sigma_{ij}}$ and $t_\gamma$ for $1\leq{i,j}\leq{b-1}$ with $i<j$.
\end{thm}

In this paper, for $f,g\in{\mathcal{M}}(N_g^b)$, the composition $gf$ means that we first apply $f$ and then $g$.




















\section{Basics on mapping class groups for non-orientable surfaces}










\subsection{On mapping class groups for non-orientable surfaces}\

Mapping class groups for orientable surfaces are generated by only Dehn twists.
Lickorish showed that ${\mathcal{M}}(N_g)$ is generated by Dehn twists and \textit{$Y$-homeomorphisms} and that the subgroup of ${\mathcal{M}}(N_g)$ generated by all Dehn twists is an index $2$ subgroup of ${\mathcal{M}}(N_g)$ (see \cite{L1,L2}).
Hence ${\mathcal{M}}(N_g)$ is not generated by only Dehn twists.
On the other hand, since a $Y$-homeomorphism acts trivially on $H_1(N_g;{\mathbb{Z}}/{2{\mathbb{Z}}})$, ${\mathcal{M}}(N_g)$ is not generated by only $Y$-homeomorphisms.

Chillingworth \cite{C} found a finite generating set for ${\mathcal{M}}(N_g)$.
${\mathcal{M}}(N_1)$ and ${\mathcal{M}}(N_1^1)$ are trivial (see \cite{E}).
Finite presentations for ${\mathcal{M}}(N_2)$, ${\mathcal{M}}(N_2^1)$, ${\mathcal{M}}(N_3)$ and ${\mathcal{M}}(N_4)$ are obtained by \cite{L1}, \cite{St1}, \cite{BC} and \cite{Sz}, respectively.
Paris-Szepietowski \cite{PS} obtained a finite presentation of ${\mathcal{M}}(N_g^b)$  for $b=0,1$ and $g+b>3$.

Let $N$ be a non-orientable surface, and let $a$ and $m$ be an oriented $A$-circle and an $M$-circle on $N$ respectively such that $a$ and $m$ mutually intersect transversely at only one point.
We now define a $Y$-homeomorphism $Y_{m,a}$.
Let $K$ be a regular neighborhood of $a\cup{b}$ in $N$, and let $M$ be a regular neighborhood of $m$ in the interior of $K$.
We can see that $K$ is homeomorphic to the Klein bottle with one boundary component.
$Y_{m,a}$ is defined as the isotopy class of a diffeomorphism over $N$ which is described by pushing $M$ once along $a$ and which fixes each point of the boundary and the exterior of $K$ (see Figure~\ref{y-homeo}).


\begin{figure}[htbp]
\includegraphics[scale=0.5]{y-homeo.eps}
\caption{The $Y$-homoemorphism $Y_{m,a}$.}\label{y-homeo}
\end{figure}











\subsection{On Torelli groups for non-orientable surfaces}\

Let $c$ be an $A$-circle on a non-orientable surface $N$ such that $N\setminus{c}$ is not connected.
We call $t_c$ a \textit{bounding simple closed curve map}, for short a \textit{BSCC} map.
For example, in Theorem~\ref{main-thm}, $t_\alpha$, $t_\gamma$, $t_{\delta_i}$, $t_{\rho_i}$ and $t_{\sigma_{ij}}$ are BSCC maps.
Let $c_1$ and $c_2$ be $A$-circles on $N$ such that $N\setminus{c_i}$ is connected, $N\setminus(c_1\cup{}c_2)$ is not connected and one of its connected components is an orientable surface with two boundary components.
We call $t_{c_1}t_{c_2}^{-1}$ a \textit{bounding pair map}, for short a \textit{BP} map.
For example, in Theorem~\ref{main-thm}, $t_\beta{}t_{\beta^\prime}^{-1}$ is a BP map.

Hirose and the author \cite{HK} obtained the following theorem.


\begin{thm}[\cite{HK}]\label{pre-thm}
For $g\geq5$, ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g)$ is normally generated by $t_\alpha$ and $t_\beta{}t_{\beta^\prime}^{-1}$ in ${\mathcal{M}}(N_g)$.
${\mathcal{I}}(N_4)$ is normally generated by $t_\alpha$, $t_\beta{}t_{\beta^\prime}^{-1}$ and $t_\gamma$ in ${\mathcal{M}}(N_4)$.
\end{thm}


Theorem~\ref{main-thm} is a natural extension of Theorem~\ref{pre-thm}.

We can check that all BSCC maps and BP maps are in ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)$.
In addition, by Theorem~\ref{main-thm}, we have that ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)$ is generated by BSCC maps and BP maps.
We do not know whether or not ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)$ can be finitely generated.

Note that a BP map of type $(2,h^\prime)$ is defined only if $g$ is even.
By the method similar to Lemma~2.1 of \cite{HK}, we have the following.



\begin{rem}\label{bscc-bp-prod}
For $g\geq4$ and $b\geq0$, we have
\begin{enumerate}
\item a BSCC map of type $(1,h,d)$ is a product of BSCC maps of types $(1,1,1)$, $(1,2,0)$, $(2,0,1)$ and $(2,0,2)$,
\item a BSCC map of type $(2,h,d)$ is a product of
	\begin{enumerate}
	\item[] BSCC maps of types $(1,1,1)$, $(1,2,0)$, $(2,0,1)$ and $(2,0,2)$ if $g-2h\geq3$,
	\item[] BSCC maps of types $(1,1,1)$, $(2,0,1)$, $(2,0,2)$ and $(2,\frac{g-2}{2},b)$ if $g-2h=2$,
	\item[] BSCC maps of types $(2,0,1)$, $(2,0,2)$ and $(2,\frac{g-1}{2},b-1)$ if $g-2h=1$,
	\end{enumerate}
\item a BP map of type $(i,h)$ is a product of BP maps of type $(i,1)$ for $i=1,2$.
\end{enumerate}
\end{rem}

\end{thm}

\subsection{ Capping, Pushing and Forgetful homomorphisms}\

Let $N$ be a compact non-orientable surface.
Take a point $\ast$ in the interior of $N$.
Let ${\mathcal{M}}(N,\ast)$ denote the group consisting of isotopy classes of all diffeomorphisms over $N$  which fix $\ast$ and each point of the boundary, and let ${\mathcal{I}}(N,\ast)$ denote the subgroup of ${\mathcal{M}}(N,\ast)$ consisting of elements acting trivially on $H_1(N;{\mathbb{Z}})$

Take a point $\ast$ in the interior of $N_g^{b-1}$.
We regard $N_g^b$ as a subsurface of $N_g^{b-1}$ not containing $\ast$.
The natural embedding $N_g^b\hookrightarrow{}N_g^{b-1}$ induces the homomorphism ${\mathcal{C}}_g^b:{\mathcal{M}}(N_g^b)\to{\mathcal{M}}(N_g^{b-1},\ast)$, called the \textit{capping homomorphism}.
We have the following lemma.



\begin{lem}[cf. \cite{FM,St2}]\label{kernel-c}
$\ker{\mathcal{C}}_g^b$ is generated by $t_{\delta_b}$.
\end{lem}



Since $t_{\delta_b}$ is in ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)$ we obtain the following.



\begin{cor}\label{kernel-c-res}
$\ker{\mathcal{C}}_g^b|_{{\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)}$ is generated by $t_{\delta_b}$.
\end{cor}



We remark that ${\mathcal{C}}_g^b$ and ${\mathcal{C}}_g^b|_{{\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)}$ are not surjective.

The \textit{pushing homomorphism} ${\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}:\pi_1(N_g^{b-1},\ast)\to{\mathcal{M}}(N_g^{b-1},\ast)$ is defined as follows.
For $x\in\pi_1(N_g^{b-1},\ast)$ take a representative oriented loop $\tilde{x}$ based at $\ast$.
${\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(x)$ is described by pushing $\ast$ once along $\tilde{x}$ and fixes each point of exterior of neighborhood of $\tilde{x}$.
Note that ${\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}$ is an anti-homomorphism, that is, for $x,y\in\pi_1(N_g^{b-1},\ast)$ we have ${\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(xy)={\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(y){\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(x)$.
The \textit{forgetful homomorphism} ${\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}:{\mathcal{M}}(N_g^{b-1},\ast)\to{\mathcal{M}}(N_g^{b-1})$ is defined naturally.
Note that ${\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}$ is surjective.

\subsection{Proof of Proposition~\ref{im-cap-torelli-n-c-1}}\

To prove Proposition~\ref{im-cap-torelli-n-c-1}, it suffices to show that for any $\varphi\in{\mathcal{I}}(N_g^{b-1})$ there is $\widetilde{\varphi}\in{\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)$ such that $({\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}\circ{\mathcal{C}}_g^b)(\widetilde{\varphi})=\varphi$.

Let $\gamma_i$ and $\delta_j$ be oriented loops on $N_g^b$ as shown in Figure~\ref{cd}, and let $c_i$ and $d_i$ be the elements of $H_1(N_g^b;Z)$ corresponding to $\gamma_i$ and $\delta_j$ respectively.
As a ${\mathbb{Z}}$-module, $H_1(N_g^b,{\mathbb{Z}})$ has a presentation

Let $\tau=\tau_{g-1g}^{n_{g-1}}\cdots\tau_{2g}^{n_2}\tau_{1g}^{n_1}$ and $\widetilde{\varphi}=\tau\psi$.
Since $({\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}\circ{\mathcal{C}}_g^b)(\tau)=1$ we have $({\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}\circ{\mathcal{C}}_g^b)(\widetilde{\varphi})=\varphi$.
For $1\leq{i}\leq{g-1}$ we calculate
\begin{eqnarray*}
\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast(c_i)
&=&\tau_\ast(\psi_\ast(c_i))\\
&=&\tau_\ast(c_i+n_id_b)\\
&=&\tau_\ast(c_i)+n_i\tau_\ast(d_b)\\
&=&(\tau_{ig})^{n_i}_\ast(c_i)+n_id_b\\
&=&(c_i-n_id_b)+n_id_b\\
&=&c_i.
\end{eqnarray*}
In addition, we calculate
\begin{eqnarray*}
\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast(c_g)
&=&\tau_\ast(\psi_\ast(c_g))\\
&=&\tau_\ast(c_g+n_gd_b)\\
&=&\tau_\ast(c_g)+n_g\tau_\ast(d_b)\\
&=&(c_g+\sum_{k=1}^{g-1}n_kd_b)+n_gd_b\\
&=&c_g+\sum_{k=1}^gn_kd_b.
\end{eqnarray*}
Let $c=2(c_1+\cdots+c_g)+(d_1+\dots+d_b)(=0)$.
We see
\begin{eqnarray*}
\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast(c)
&=&2(\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast(c_1)+\cdots+\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast(c_g))+(\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast(d_1)+\cdots+\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast(d_b))\\
&=&2(c_1+\cdots+c_{g-1}+c_g+\sum_{k=1}^gn_kd_b)+(d_1+\dots+d_b)\\
&=&c+2\sum_{k=1}^gn_kd_b\\
&=&2\sum_{k=1}^gn_kd_b.
\end{eqnarray*}
Since $\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast(c)=0$ we have $\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^gn_k=0$, and hence $\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast(c_g)=c_g$.
Hence we have that $\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast$ is the identity.
Therefore we conclude that $\widetilde{\varphi}$ is in ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)$ with $({\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}\circ{\mathcal{C}}_g^b)(\widetilde{\varphi})=\varphi$.
Thus we complete the proof of Proposition~\ref{im-cap-torelli-n-c-1}.

\begin{lem}\label{ijkl}
For $1\leq{i,j,k,l}\leq{g}$, we have $x_{ij}x_{kl}=x_{kl}x_{ij}$.
\end{lem}





\begin{proof}
If $(i,j,k,l)=(i,i,i,i)$, $(i,i,k,i)$, $(i,i,i,l)$, $(i,i,k,k)$, $(i,j,i,j)$, $(i,j,j,i)$ and $(i,i,k,l)$, it is clear that $x_{ij}x_{kl}=x_{kl}x_{ij}$.
Hence we check the cases where $(i,j,k,l)=(i,j,i,l)$, $(i,j,k,j)$, $(i,j,k,i)$ and $(i,j,k,l)$.
For any $1\leq{i,j}\leq{g}$ since $x_{ij}$ acts trivially on $d_1,d_2,\dots,d_b$, we check the actions on $c_1,c_2,\dots,c_g$.

For any mutually different indices $1\leq{i,j,l}\leq{g}$ we see
\begin{eqnarray*}
x_{ij}x_{il}(c_t)&=&
\left\{
\begin{array}{llll}
x_{ij}(c_i-d_b)&=&c_i-2d_b&(t=i),\\
x_{ij}(c_j)&=&c_j+d_b&(t=j),\\
x_{ij}(c_l+d_b)&=&c_l+d_b&(t=l),\\
x_{ij}(c_t)&=&c_t&(t\neq{i,j,l}),
\end{array}
\right.\\
x_{il}x_{ij}(c_t)&=&
\left\{
\begin{array}{llll}
x_{il}(c_i-d_b)&=&c_i-2d_b&(t=i),\\
x_{il}(c_j+d_b)&=&c_j+d_b&(t=j),\\
x_{il}(c_l)&=&c_l+d_b&(t=l),\\
x_{il}(c_t)&=&c_t&(t\neq{i,j,l}).
\end{array}
\right.
\end{eqnarray*}
Hence we have $x_{ij}x_{il}=x_{il}x_{ij}$.

For any mutually different indices $1\leq{i,j,k}\leq{g}$ we see
\begin{eqnarray*}
x_{ij}x_{kj}(c_t)&=&
\left\{
\begin{array}{llll}
x_{ij}(c_i)&=&c_i-d_b&(t=i),\\
x_{ij}(c_j+d_b)&=&c_j+2d_b&(t=j),\\
x_{ij}(c_k-d_b)&=&c_k-d_b&(t=k),\\
x_{ij}(c_t)&=&c_t&(t\neq{i,j,k}),
\end{array}
\right.\\
x_{kj}x_{ij}(c_t)&=&
\left\{
\begin{array}{llll}
x_{kj}(c_i-d_b)&=&c_i-d_b&(t=i),\\
x_{kj}(c_j+d_b)&=&c_j+2d_b&(t=j),\\
x_{kj}(c_k)&=&c_k-d_b&(t=k),\\
x_{kj}(c_t)&=&c_t&(t\neq{i,j,k}).
\end{array}
\right.
\end{eqnarray*}
Hence we have $x_{ij}x_{kj}=x_{kj}x_{ij}$.

For any mutually different indices $1\leq{i,j,k}\leq{g}$ we see
\begin{eqnarray*}
x_{ij}x_{ki}(c_t)&=&
\left\{
\begin{array}{llll}
x_{ij}(c_i+d_b)&=&c_i&(t=i),\\
x_{ij}(c_j)&=&c_j+d_b&(t=j),\\
x_{ij}(c_k-d_b)&=&c_k-d_b&(t=k),\\
x_{ij}(c_t)&=&c_t&(t\neq{i,j,k}),
\end{array}
\right.\\
x_{ki}x_{ij}(c_t)&=&
\left\{
\begin{array}{llll}
x_{ki}(c_i-d_b)&=&c_i&(t=i),\\
x_{ki}(c_j+d_b)&=&c_j+d_b&(t=j),\\
x_{ki}(c_k)&=&c_k-d_b&(t=k),\\
x_{ki}(c_t)&=&c_t&(t\neq{i,j,k}).
\end{array}
\right.
\end{eqnarray*}
Hence we have $x_{ij}x_{ki}=x_{ki}x_{ij}$.

For any mutually different indices $1\leq{i,j,k,l}\leq{g}$ we see
\begin{eqnarray*}
x_{ij}x_{kl}(c_t)&=&
\left\{
\begin{array}{llll}
x_{ij}(c_i)&=&c_i-d_b&(t=i),\\
x_{ij}(c_j)&=&c_j+d_b&(t=j),\\
x_{ij}(c_k-d_b)&=&c_k-d_b&(t=k),\\
x_{ij}(c_l+d_b)&=&c_l+d_b&(t=l),\\
x_{ij}(c_t)&=&c_t&(t\neq{i,j,k,l}),
\end{array}
\right.\\
x_{kl}x_{ij}(c_t)&=&
\left\{
\begin{array}{llll}
x_{kl}(c_i-d_b)&=&c_i-d_b&(t=i),\\
x_{kl}(c_j+d_b)&=&c_j+d_b&(t=j),\\
x_{kl}(c_k)&=&c_k-d_b&(t=k),\\
x_{kl}(c_l)&=&c_l+d_b&(t=l),\\
x_{kl}(c_t)&=&c_t&(t\neq{i,j,k,l}).
\end{array}
\right.
\end{eqnarray*}
Hence we have $x_{ij}x_{kl}=x_{kl}x_{ij}$.

Thus we obtain the claim.
\end{proof}



For $x\in\pi_1^+(N_g^{b-1},\ast)$ denote $p(x)=x_{i_1}^{\varepsilon_1}x_{i_2}^{\varepsilon_2}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}^{\varepsilon_{2l}}$.
Since $(y_j)_\ast=1$, we have $x_\ast=x_{i_1i_2}x_{i_3i_4}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l-1}i_{2l}}$.
For $1\leq{i}\leq{g}$, let $s=\sharp\{k\mid{}i_{2k-1}=i_{2k}=i\}$, $t=O_i(x)-s$ and $u=E_i(x)-s$.
Since $x_{ii}=1$ and $x_{kl}(c_i)=c_i$, by Lemma~\ref{ijkl} we have
\begin{eqnarray*}
x_\ast(c_i)
&=&x_{k(u)i}\cdots{}x_{k(1)i}\cdot{}x_{ij(t)}\cdots{}x_{ij(1)}\cdot{}x_{ii}^s(c_i)\\
&=&x_{k(u)i}\cdots{}x_{k(1)i}\cdot{}x_{ij(t)}\cdots{}x_{ij(1)}(c_i)\\
&=&x_{k(u)i}\cdots{}x_{k(1)i}(c_i-td_b)\\
&=&(c_i+ud_b)-td_b\\
&=&c_i+(u-t)d_b,
\end{eqnarray*}
using the suitable indices $j(1),\dots,j(t)$ and $k(1),\dots,k(u)$.
Therefore we have that $x\in\Gamma_g^{b-1}$ if and only if $x_\ast=1$.

Note that $\ker{\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}|_{{\mathcal{C}}_g^b({\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b))}$ is equal to the intersection of $\ker{\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}$ and ${\mathcal{C}}_g^b({\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b))$.
For any $x\in\Gamma_g^{b-1}$, since $x_\ast=1$, we have that ${\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(x)$ is in ${\mathcal{C}}_g^b({\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b))$.
In addition, since ${\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(x)$ is in $\ker{\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}$, we have that ${\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(x)$ is in $\ker{\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}|_{{\mathcal{C}}_g^b({\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b))}$.
Hence we conclude ${\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(\Gamma_g^{b-1})\subset\ker{\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}|_{{\mathcal{C}}_g^b({\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b))}$.

For any $\varphi\in\ker{\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}|_{{\mathcal{C}}_g^b({\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b))}$, since $\varphi$ is in $\ker{\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}$ there exists $x\in\pi_1(N_g^{b-1},\ast)$ such that $\varphi={\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(x)$.
In addition, since $\varphi$ is in ${\mathcal{C}}_g^b({\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b))$ we have $x_\ast=1$, and hence $x\in\Gamma_g^{b-1}$.
Hence $\varphi$ is in ${\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(\Gamma_g^{b-1})$.
Therefore we conclude $\ker{\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}|_{{\mathcal{C}}_g^b({\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b))}\subset{\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(\Gamma_g^{b-1})$.

Thus we complete the proof of Proposition~\ref{im-cap-torelli-n-c-2}.










\subsection{Proof of Proposition~\ref{p-g}}\

Let $\pi_g^{b-1}$ denote the finitely presented group with the generators $x_i$ and $y_j$, and with the relators $x_i^2$, $y_j$ and $[x_{i(1)}x_{i(2)},x_{i(3)}x_{i(4)}]$, where $1\leq{i,i(1),i(2),i(3),i(4)}\leq{g}$, $1\leq{j}\leq{b-1}$ and $[x,y]$ means $xyx^{-1}y^{-1}$.
There is the natural surjection $\psi:\pi_1(N_g^{b-1},\ast)\to\pi_g^{b-1}$.
We first show the following lemma.



\begin{lem}\label{pi-lem1}
$\Gamma_g^{b-1}$ is equal to $\ker\psi$.
\end{lem}





\begin{proof}
It is clear that $\Gamma_g^{b-1}\supset\ker\psi$.
We show $\Gamma_g^{b-1}\subset\ker\psi$.
Namely, it suffices to show that $x\equiv1$ modulo $x_i^2$, $y_j$ and $[x_{i(1)}x_{i(2)},x_{i(3)}x_{i(4)}]$ for any $x\in\Gamma_g^{b-1}$.

For any $x\in\Gamma_g^{b-1}$ we can denote $x\equiv{}x_{i_1}x_{i_2}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}$ modulo $x_i^2$ and $y_j$.
Since $O_{i_1}(x)=E_{i_1}(x)$, there exists $1\leq{t}\leq{l}$ such that $i_1=i_{2t}$.
Hence, modulo $x_i^2$, $y_j$ and $[x_{i(1)}x_{i(2)},x_{i(3)}x_{i(4)}]$, we calculate
\begin{eqnarray*}
x
&\equiv&x_{i_1}x_{i_2}\cdots{}x_{i_{2t}}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t+1}}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}\\
&=&[x_{i_1}x_{i_2},x_{i_3}x_{i_4}]x_{i_3}x_{i_4}x_{i_1}x_{i_2}\cdot{}x_{i_5}x_{i_6}\cdots{}x_{i_{2t}}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t+1}}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}\\
&\equiv&x_{i_3}x_{i_4}x_{i_1}x_{i_2}\cdot{}x_{i_5}x_{i_6}\cdots{}x_{i_{2t}}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t+1}}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}\\
&=&x_{i_3}x_{i_4}[x_{i_1}x_{i_2},x_{i_5}x_{i_6}]x_{i_5}x_{i_6}x_{i_1}x_{i_2}\cdot{}x_{i_7}x_{i_8}\cdots{}x_{i_{2t}}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t+1}}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}\\
&\equiv&x_{i_3}x_{i_4}x_{i_5}x_{i_6}x_{i_1}x_{i_2}\cdot{}x_{i_7}x_{i_8}\cdots{}x_{i_{2t}}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t+1}}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}\\
&\vdots&\\
&=&x_{i_3}\cdots{}x_{i_{2t-2}}[x_{i_1}x_{i_2},x_{i_{2t-1}}x_{i_{2t}}]x_{i_{2t-1}}x_{i_{2t}}x_{i_1}x_{i_2}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t+1}}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}\\
&\equiv&x_{i_3}\cdots{}x_{i_{2t-1}}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t}}x_{i_1}\cdot{}x_{i_2}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t+1}}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}\\
&\equiv&x_{i_3}\cdots{}x_{i_{2t-1}}\cdot{}x_{i_2}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t+1}}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}.
\end{eqnarray*}
Let $x^\prime=x_{i_3}\cdots{}x_{i_{2t-1}}\cdot{}x_{i_2}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t+1}}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}$.
It immediately follows that the word length of $x^\prime$ is $2l-2$ and $x^\prime$ is in $\Gamma_g^{b-1}$.
Since $O_{i_3}(x^\prime)=E_{i_3}(x^\prime)$, there exists $2\leq{t^\prime}\leq{l}$ such that $i_3=i_{2t^\prime}$.
Then, similarly there exists $x^{\prime\prime}$ such that the word length of $x^{\prime\prime}$ is $2l-4$, $x^{\prime\prime}$ is in $\Gamma_g^{b-1}$ and $x^\prime\equiv{}x^{\prime\prime}$ modulo $x_i^2$, $y_j$ and $[x_{i(1)}x_{i(2)},x_{i(3)}x_{i(4)}]$.
Repeating the same operation, we have that $x\equiv{}x^\prime\equiv{}x^{\prime\prime}\equiv\cdots\equiv1$ modulo $x_i^2$, $y_j$ and $[x_{i(1)}x_{i(2)},x_{i(3)}x_{i(4)}]$.
Therefore we have $x\in\ker\psi$.

Thus we obtain the claim.
\end{proof}

\begin{lem}\label{pi-lem2}
$\pi_g^{b-1}$ has a presentation with

Let $\tau=\tau_{g-1g}^{n_{g-1}}\cdots\tau_{2g}^{n_2}\tau_{1g}^{n_1}$ and $\widetilde{\varphi}=\tau\psi$.
Since $({\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}\circ{\mathcal{C}}_g^b)(\tau)=1$ we have $({\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}\circ{\mathcal{C}}_g^b)(\widetilde{\varphi})=\varphi$.
For $1\leq{i}\leq{g-1}$ we calculate
\begin{eqnarray*}
\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast(c_i)
&=&\tau_\ast(\psi_\ast(c_i))\\
&=&\tau_\ast(c_i+n_id_b)\\
&=&\tau_\ast(c_i)+n_i\tau_\ast(d_b)\\
&=&(\tau_{ig})^{n_i}_\ast(c_i)+n_id_b\\
&=&(c_i-n_id_b)+n_id_b\\
&=&c_i.
\end{eqnarray*}
In addition, we calculate
\begin{eqnarray*}
\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast(c_g)
&=&\tau_\ast(\psi_\ast(c_g))\\
&=&\tau_\ast(c_g+n_gd_b)\\
&=&\tau_\ast(c_g)+n_g\tau_\ast(d_b)\\
&=&(c_g+\sum_{k=1}^{g-1}n_kd_b)+n_gd_b\\
&=&c_g+\sum_{k=1}^gn_kd_b.
\end{eqnarray*}
Let $c=2(c_1+\cdots+c_g)+(d_1+\dots+d_b)(=0)$.
We see
\begin{eqnarray*}
\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast(c)
&=&2(\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast(c_1)+\cdots+\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast(c_g))+(\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast(d_1)+\cdots+\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast(d_b))\\
&=&2(c_1+\cdots+c_{g-1}+c_g+\sum_{k=1}^gn_kd_b)+(d_1+\dots+d_b)\\
&=&c+2\sum_{k=1}^gn_kd_b\\
&=&2\sum_{k=1}^gn_kd_b.
\end{eqnarray*}
Since $\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast(c)=0$ we have $\displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^gn_k=0$, and hence $\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast(c_g)=c_g$.
Hence we have that $\widetilde{\varphi}_\ast$ is the identity.
Therefore we conclude that $\widetilde{\varphi}$ is in ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)$ with $({\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}\circ{\mathcal{C}}_g^b)(\widetilde{\varphi})=\varphi$.
Thus we complete the proof of Proposition~\ref{im-cap-torelli-n-c-1}.










\subsection{Proof of Proposition~\ref{im-cap-torelli-n-c-2}}\

Note that ${\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(x)$ can be lifted by ${\mathcal{C}}_g^b$ if and only if the word length of $p(x)\in\pi_1(N_g,\ast)$ is even.

For example, the natural lifts of ${\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(x_g^2)$ and ${\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(y_j)$ are $t_{\rho_b}$ and $t_{\sigma_{jb}}t_{\delta_j}^{-1}$, respectively.

It suffices to show that $(x_ix_jx_k)^2$ is a product of conjugations of some $[x_{i(1)}x_{i(2)},x_{i(3)}x_{i(4)}]$ and that $[x_{i(1)}x_{i(2)},x_{i(3)}x_{i(4)}]$ is a product of conjugations of some $(x_ix_jx_k)^2$, modulo $x_1^2,x_2^2,\dots,x_g^2$.

\begin{eqnarray*}
(x_ix_jx_k)^2

If $(i(1),i(2),i(3),i(4))=(i,i,i,i)$, $(i,i,i,j)$, $(i,i,j,i)$, $(i,j,i,i)$, $(j,i,i,i)$ $(i,i,j,j)$, $(i,j,i,j)$, $(i,j,j,i)$, $(i,i,j,k)$ and $(i,j,k,k)$, we have immediately that $[x_{i(1)}x_{i(2)},x_{i(3)}x_{i(4)}]\equiv1$ modulo $x_1^2,x_2^2,\dots,x_g^2$.

\begin{lem}\label{ijkl}
For $1\leq{i,j,k,l}\leq{g}$, we have $x_{ij}x_{kl}=x_{kl}x_{ij}$.
\end{lem}





\begin{proof}
If $(i,j,k,l)=(i,i,i,i)$, $(i,i,k,i)$, $(i,i,i,l)$, $(i,i,k,k)$, $(i,j,i,j)$, $(i,j,j,i)$ and $(i,i,k,l)$, it is clear that $x_{ij}x_{kl}=x_{kl}x_{ij}$.
Hence we check the cases where $(i,j,k,l)=(i,j,i,l)$, $(i,j,k,j)$, $(i,j,k,i)$ and $(i,j,k,l)$.
For any $1\leq{i,j}\leq{g}$ since $x_{ij}$ acts trivially on $d_1,d_2,\dots,d_b$, we check the actions on $c_1,c_2,\dots,c_g$.

For any mutually different indices $1\leq{i,j,l}\leq{g}$ we see
\begin{eqnarray*}
x_{ij}x_{il}(c_t)&=&
\left\{
\begin{array}{llll}
x_{ij}(c_i-d_b)&=&c_i-2d_b&(t=i),\\
x_{ij}(c_j)&=&c_j+d_b&(t=j),\\
x_{ij}(c_l+d_b)&=&c_l+d_b&(t=l),\\
x_{ij}(c_t)&=&c_t&(t\neq{i,j,l}),
\end{array}
\right.\\
x_{il}x_{ij}(c_t)&=&
\left\{
\begin{array}{llll}
x_{il}(c_i-d_b)&=&c_i-2d_b&(t=i),\\
x_{il}(c_j+d_b)&=&c_j+d_b&(t=j),\\
x_{il}(c_l)&=&c_l+d_b&(t=l),\\
x_{il}(c_t)&=&c_t&(t\neq{i,j,l}).
\end{array}
\right.
\end{eqnarray*}
Hence we have $x_{ij}x_{il}=x_{il}x_{ij}$.

For any mutually different indices $1\leq{i,j,k}\leq{g}$ we see
\begin{eqnarray*}
x_{ij}x_{kj}(c_t)&=&
\left\{
\begin{array}{llll}
x_{ij}(c_i)&=&c_i-d_b&(t=i),\\
x_{ij}(c_j+d_b)&=&c_j+2d_b&(t=j),\\
x_{ij}(c_k-d_b)&=&c_k-d_b&(t=k),\\
x_{ij}(c_t)&=&c_t&(t\neq{i,j,k}),
\end{array}
\right.\\
x_{kj}x_{ij}(c_t)&=&
\left\{
\begin{array}{llll}
x_{kj}(c_i-d_b)&=&c_i-d_b&(t=i),\\
x_{kj}(c_j+d_b)&=&c_j+2d_b&(t=j),\\
x_{kj}(c_k)&=&c_k-d_b&(t=k),\\
x_{kj}(c_t)&=&c_t&(t\neq{i,j,k}).
\end{array}
\right.
\end{eqnarray*}
Hence we have $x_{ij}x_{kj}=x_{kj}x_{ij}$.

For any mutually different indices $1\leq{i,j,k}\leq{g}$ we see
\begin{eqnarray*}
x_{ij}x_{ki}(c_t)&=&
\left\{
\begin{array}{llll}
x_{ij}(c_i+d_b)&=&c_i&(t=i),\\
x_{ij}(c_j)&=&c_j+d_b&(t=j),\\
x_{ij}(c_k-d_b)&=&c_k-d_b&(t=k),\\
x_{ij}(c_t)&=&c_t&(t\neq{i,j,k}),
\end{array}
\right.\\
x_{ki}x_{ij}(c_t)&=&
\left\{
\begin{array}{llll}
x_{ki}(c_i-d_b)&=&c_i&(t=i),\\
x_{ki}(c_j+d_b)&=&c_j+d_b&(t=j),\\
x_{ki}(c_k)&=&c_k-d_b&(t=k),\\
x_{ki}(c_t)&=&c_t&(t\neq{i,j,k}).
\end{array}
\right.
\end{eqnarray*}
Hence we have $x_{ij}x_{ki}=x_{ki}x_{ij}$.

For any mutually different indices $1\leq{i,j,k,l}\leq{g}$ we see
\begin{eqnarray*}
x_{ij}x_{kl}(c_t)&=&
\left\{
\begin{array}{llll}
x_{ij}(c_i)&=&c_i-d_b&(t=i),\\
x_{ij}(c_j)&=&c_j+d_b&(t=j),\\
x_{ij}(c_k-d_b)&=&c_k-d_b&(t=k),\\
x_{ij}(c_l+d_b)&=&c_l+d_b&(t=l),\\
x_{ij}(c_t)&=&c_t&(t\neq{i,j,k,l}),
\end{array}
\right.\\
x_{kl}x_{ij}(c_t)&=&
\left\{
\begin{array}{llll}
x_{kl}(c_i-d_b)&=&c_i-d_b&(t=i),\\
x_{kl}(c_j+d_b)&=&c_j+d_b&(t=j),\\
x_{kl}(c_k)&=&c_k-d_b&(t=k),\\
x_{kl}(c_l)&=&c_l+d_b&(t=l),\\
x_{kl}(c_t)&=&c_t&(t\neq{i,j,k,l}).
\end{array}
\right.
\end{eqnarray*}
Hence we have $x_{ij}x_{kl}=x_{kl}x_{ij}$.

Thus we obtain the claim.
\end{proof}



For $x\in\pi_1^+(N_g^{b-1},\ast)$ denote $p(x)=x_{i_1}^{\varepsilon_1}x_{i_2}^{\varepsilon_2}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}^{\varepsilon_{2l}}$.
Since $(y_j)_\ast=1$, we have $x_\ast=x_{i_1i_2}x_{i_3i_4}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l-1}i_{2l}}$.
For $1\leq{i}\leq{g}$, let $s=\sharp\{k\mid{}i_{2k-1}=i_{2k}=i\}$, $t=O_i(x)-s$ and $u=E_i(x)-s$.
Since $x_{ii}=1$ and $x_{kl}(c_i)=c_i$, by Lemma~\ref{ijkl} we have
\begin{eqnarray*}
x_\ast(c_i)
&=&x_{k(u)i}\cdots{}x_{k(1)i}\cdot{}x_{ij(t)}\cdots{}x_{ij(1)}\cdot{}x_{ii}^s(c_i)\\
&=&x_{k(u)i}\cdots{}x_{k(1)i}\cdot{}x_{ij(t)}\cdots{}x_{ij(1)}(c_i)\\
&=&x_{k(u)i}\cdots{}x_{k(1)i}(c_i-td_b)\\
&=&(c_i+ud_b)-td_b\\
&=&c_i+(u-t)d_b,
\end{eqnarray*}
using the suitable indices $j(1),\dots,j(t)$ and $k(1),\dots,k(u)$.
Therefore we have that $x\in\Gamma_g^{b-1}$ if and only if $x_\ast=1$.

Note that $\ker{\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}|_{{\mathcal{C}}_g^b({\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b))}$ is equal to the intersection of $\ker{\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}$ and ${\mathcal{C}}_g^b({\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b))$.
For any $x\in\Gamma_g^{b-1}$, since $x_\ast=1$, we have that ${\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(x)$ is in ${\mathcal{C}}_g^b({\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b))$.
In addition, since ${\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(x)$ is in $\ker{\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}$, we have that ${\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(x)$ is in $\ker{\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}|_{{\mathcal{C}}_g^b({\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b))}$.
Hence we conclude ${\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(\Gamma_g^{b-1})\subset\ker{\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}|_{{\mathcal{C}}_g^b({\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b))}$.

For any $\varphi\in\ker{\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}|_{{\mathcal{C}}_g^b({\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b))}$, since $\varphi$ is in $\ker{\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}$ there exists $x\in\pi_1(N_g^{b-1},\ast)$ such that $\varphi={\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(x)$.
In addition, since $\varphi$ is in ${\mathcal{C}}_g^b({\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b))$ we have $x_\ast=1$, and hence $x\in\Gamma_g^{b-1}$.
Hence $\varphi$ is in ${\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(\Gamma_g^{b-1})$.
Therefore we conclude $\ker{\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}|_{{\mathcal{C}}_g^b({\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b))}\subset{\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(\Gamma_g^{b-1})$.

Thus we complete the proof of Proposition~\ref{im-cap-torelli-n-c-2}.










\subsection{Proof of Proposition~\ref{p-g}}\

Let $\pi_g^{b-1}$ denote the finitely presented group with the generators $x_i$ and $y_j$, and with the relators $x_i^2$, $y_j$ and $[x_{i(1)}x_{i(2)},x_{i(3)}x_{i(4)}]$, where $1\leq{i,i(1),i(2),i(3),i(4)}\leq{g}$, $1\leq{j}\leq{b-1}$ and $[x,y]$ means $xyx^{-1}y^{-1}$.
There is the natural surjection $\psi:\pi_1(N_g^{b-1},\ast)\to\pi_g^{b-1}$.
We first show the following lemma.



\begin{lem}\label{pi-lem1}
$\Gamma_g^{b-1}$ is equal to $\ker\psi$.
\end{lem}





\begin{proof}
It is clear that $\Gamma_g^{b-1}\supset\ker\psi$.
We show $\Gamma_g^{b-1}\subset\ker\psi$.
Namely, it suffices to show that $x\equiv1$ modulo $x_i^2$, $y_j$ and $[x_{i(1)}x_{i(2)},x_{i(3)}x_{i(4)}]$ for any $x\in\Gamma_g^{b-1}$.

For any $x\in\Gamma_g^{b-1}$ we can denote $x\equiv{}x_{i_1}x_{i_2}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}$ modulo $x_i^2$ and $y_j$.
Since $O_{i_1}(x)=E_{i_1}(x)$, there exists $1\leq{t}\leq{l}$ such that $i_1=i_{2t}$.
Hence, modulo $x_i^2$, $y_j$ and $[x_{i(1)}x_{i(2)},x_{i(3)}x_{i(4)}]$, we calculate
\begin{eqnarray*}
x
&\equiv&x_{i_1}x_{i_2}\cdots{}x_{i_{2t}}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t+1}}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}\\
&=&[x_{i_1}x_{i_2},x_{i_3}x_{i_4}]x_{i_3}x_{i_4}x_{i_1}x_{i_2}\cdot{}x_{i_5}x_{i_6}\cdots{}x_{i_{2t}}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t+1}}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}\\
&\equiv&x_{i_3}x_{i_4}x_{i_1}x_{i_2}\cdot{}x_{i_5}x_{i_6}\cdots{}x_{i_{2t}}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t+1}}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}\\
&=&x_{i_3}x_{i_4}[x_{i_1}x_{i_2},x_{i_5}x_{i_6}]x_{i_5}x_{i_6}x_{i_1}x_{i_2}\cdot{}x_{i_7}x_{i_8}\cdots{}x_{i_{2t}}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t+1}}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}\\
&\equiv&x_{i_3}x_{i_4}x_{i_5}x_{i_6}x_{i_1}x_{i_2}\cdot{}x_{i_7}x_{i_8}\cdots{}x_{i_{2t}}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t+1}}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}\\
&\vdots&\\
&=&x_{i_3}\cdots{}x_{i_{2t-2}}[x_{i_1}x_{i_2},x_{i_{2t-1}}x_{i_{2t}}]x_{i_{2t-1}}x_{i_{2t}}x_{i_1}x_{i_2}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t+1}}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}\\
&\equiv&x_{i_3}\cdots{}x_{i_{2t-1}}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t}}x_{i_1}\cdot{}x_{i_2}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t+1}}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}\\
&\equiv&x_{i_3}\cdots{}x_{i_{2t-1}}\cdot{}x_{i_2}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t+1}}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}.
\end{eqnarray*}
Let $x^\prime=x_{i_3}\cdots{}x_{i_{2t-1}}\cdot{}x_{i_2}\cdot{}x_{i_{2t+1}}\cdots{}x_{i_{2l}}$.
It immediately follows that the word length of $x^\prime$ is $2l-2$ and $x^\prime$ is in $\Gamma_g^{b-1}$.
Since $O_{i_3}(x^\prime)=E_{i_3}(x^\prime)$, there exists $2\leq{t^\prime}\leq{l}$ such that $i_3=i_{2t^\prime}$.
Then, similarly there exists $x^{\prime\prime}$ such that the word length of $x^{\prime\prime}$ is $2l-4$, $x^{\prime\prime}$ is in $\Gamma_g^{b-1}$ and $x^\prime\equiv{}x^{\prime\prime}$ modulo $x_i^2$, $y_j$ and $[x_{i(1)}x_{i(2)},x_{i(3)}x_{i(4)}]$.
Repeating the same operation, we have that $x\equiv{}x^\prime\equiv{}x^{\prime\prime}\equiv\cdots\equiv1$ modulo $x_i^2$, $y_j$ and $[x_{i(1)}x_{i(2)},x_{i(3)}x_{i(4)}]$.
Therefore we have $x\in\ker\psi$.

Thus we obtain the claim.
\end{proof}

\end{lem}





\begin{proof}
It suffices to show that $(x_ix_jx_k)^2$ is a product of conjugations of some $[x_{i(1)}x_{i(2)},x_{i(3)}x_{i(4)}]$ and that $[x_{i(1)}x_{i(2)},x_{i(3)}x_{i(4)}]$ is a product of conjugations of some $(x_ix_jx_k)^2$, modulo $x_1^2,x_2^2,\dots,x_g^2$.

For any $1\leq{i<j<k}\leq{g}$, modulo $x_1^2,x_2^2,\dots,x_g^2$ we see
\begin{eqnarray*}
(x_ix_jx_k)^2
&\equiv&(x_ix_jx_k)x_jx_j(x_ix_jx_k)\\
&=&x_ix_j\cdot{}x_kx_j\cdot{}x_jx_i\cdot{}x_jx_k\\

If $(i(1),i(2),i(3),i(4))=(i,i,i,i)$, $(i,i,i,j)$, $(i,i,j,i)$, $(i,j,i,i)$, $(j,i,i,i)$ $(i,i,j,j)$, $(i,j,i,j)$, $(i,j,j,i)$, $(i,i,j,k)$ and $(i,j,k,k)$, we have immediately that $[x_{i(1)}x_{i(2)},x_{i(3)}x_{i(4)}]\equiv1$ modulo $x_1^2,x_2^2,\dots,x_g^2$.
Hence we check the other cases.

For mutually different indices $1\leq{i,j,k,l}\leq{g}$, modulo $x_1^2,x_2^2,\dots,x_g^2$ we see

~[x_ix_j,x_kx_j]

~[x_ix_j,x_kx_i]

&\equiv&(x_ix_jx_k)^2x_kx_jx_i\cdot{}x_ix_jx_l(x_lx_jx_i)^2x_lx_k\\
&\equiv&(x_ix_jx_k)^2x_kx_l(x_lx_jx_i)^2(x_kx_l)^{-1}

For the relator $(x_ix_jx_k)^2$, applying conjugations and taking their inverses, it suffices to consider the case $i<j<k$.

By Corollary~\ref{kernel-c-res} and Corollary~\ref{im-cap-torelli-n-g}, we have that ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)$ is normally generated by $t_{\delta_b}$, the lift $t_{\rho_b}$ by ${\mathcal{C}}_g^b$ of ${\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(x_g^2)$, the lift $t_{\sigma_{jb}}t_{\delta_j}^{-1}$ by ${\mathcal{C}}_g^b$ of ${\mathcal{P}}_g^{b-1}(y_j)$ and lifts by $({\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}\circ{\mathcal{C}}_g^b)|_{{\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)}$ of normal generators of ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^{b-1})$.
We prove Theorem~\ref{main-thm} by induction on the number $b$ of the boundary components of $N_g^b$.
We take the natural lift by $({\mathcal{F}}_g^{b-1}\circ{\mathcal{C}}_g^b)|_{{\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)}$ of a normal generator of ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^{b-1})$.

At first, ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g)$ is normally generated by $t_\alpha$, $t_\beta{}t_{\beta^\prime}^{-1}$ and $t_\gamma$ (see \cite{HK}).
Hence we have that ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^1)$ is normally generated by $t_\alpha$, $t_\beta{}t_{\beta^\prime}^{-1}$, $t_\gamma$ and $t_{\delta_1}$, $t_{\rho_1}$.
Similarly we have that ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^2)$ is normally generated by $t_\alpha$, $t_\beta{}t_{\beta^\prime}^{-1}$, $t_\gamma$, $t_{\delta_1}$, $t_{\rho_1}$ and $t_{\delta_2}$, $t_{\rho_2}$, $t_{\sigma_{12}}$.
For $b\geq3$, suppose that ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^{b-1})$ is normally generated by $t_\alpha$, $t_\beta{}t_{\beta^\prime}^{-1}$, $t_\gamma$, $t_{\delta_i}$, $t_{\rho_i}$ and $t_{\sigma_{ij}}$ for $1\leq{i,j}\leq{b-1}$ with $i<j$.
Then we have that ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)$ is normally generated by $t_\alpha$, $t_\beta{}t_{\beta^\prime}^{-1}$, $t_\gamma$, $t_{\delta_i}$, $t_{\rho_i}$, $t_{\sigma_{ij}}$ and $t_{\delta_b}$, $t_{\rho_b}$, $t_{\sigma_{kb}}$, for $1\leq{i,j,k}\leq{b-1}$ with $i<j$.
Hence we obtain a normal generating set for ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)$.
In particular, for $g\geq5$ since ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g)$ is normally generated by $t_\alpha$ and $t_\beta{}t_{\beta^\prime}^{-1}$ (see \cite{HK}), we do not need $t_\gamma$ as a normal generator of ${\mathcal{I}}(N_g^b)$ for $g\geq5$.
Finally, proving the following lemma, we finish the proof of Theorem~\ref{main-thm}.
